awd_titl_txt: CAREER:Tissue-engineering an aging heart: The effect of aged cell microenvironment in myocardial infarction
awd_abstract_narration:
PI:  Zorlutuna, Pinar
Proposal #:  1651385

Most deadly diseases, and particularly cardiovascular diseases, occur more often in older people, with age being the primary risk factor. Therefore, an urgent need exists for a better understanding of disease progress in aged tissues in order to find ways to decrease age-related problems.  This project focuses on establishing a unique tissue engineered model system of the aging human myocardium that can be used to investigate the role of the aging tissue microenvironment on cell survival after a heart attack/myocardial infarction (MI).  The novel model overcomes limitations 1) of animal models that have limited applicability to the human condition and involve complex systems with difficult to control parameters and 2) of cell culture models that are oversimplified.   Studies are designed to test the hypothesis that the aging tissue microenvironment (i.e., biochemical composition and biophysical properties such as stiffness of the extracellular matrix (ECM)) affects cell survival after MI, and the decreased cellular communication due to cellular damage is the cause of increased cell death in older tissues.  Research and education are integrated through undergraduate and graduate training and mentoring activities and a three-day summer workshop titled "Peace through Science" that aims to leverage science to teach tolerance and inclusion.

As part of the long-term career goal to establish a research program focused on biomimetic engineered model tissues to investigate the multicellular communication and cell-microenvironment interactions in healthy and diseased tissues, the focus of this project is the first study to demonstrate that tissue engineering and microfabrication can create highly impactful aging-mimicking disease models and that these models can be used to elucidate the role of aging on a specific disease--myocardial infarction. Specific hypotheses to be tested are: 1) matrix age affects cell survival due to altered biochemical and biophysical matrix content by age, 2) chronological age of cells affects cell survival due to altered paracrine factor secretion by the cells by age and 3) cellular damage that accumulates by age in myocardial tissue causes decreased cellular function and interaction, resulting in increased cell death upon MI in older tissues.  The related research objectives are to 1) create an aging mimicking myocardial model tissue that can be used to simulate MI conditions and 2) study the effect of the aging tissue microenvironment on cell survival upon MI.  The engineered myocardial tissue model will be microfabricated using human induced pluripotent stem cell-derived endothelial and myocardial cells, biomimetic hydrogels and microfluidics.  Cellular communication will be studied under MI-mimicking conditions (i.e., hypoxia, nutrient starvation, reperfusion and oxidative stress.)  The knowledge gained using this model tissue will unravel the cellular communication within normal, aging and diseased myocardium and will shed light on both the cell-level phenomena upon MI and on the nature of aging itself.  As only 10% of therapies that are shown to be successful in animal models pass clinical trials, engineered tissue models using human cells are gaining much interest due to their advantages over animal models and their potential to increase clinical translation of basic science by filling the gap between in vitro and in vivo studies.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF NOTRE DAME DU LAC

por.por_cntn:
Cardiovascular diseases (CVD) are the leading cause of death. CVD occur more often in the older people, as aging is the primary risk factor. Current animal models and simple cell cultures fall short to fully mimic the disease progression in the aged human heart. Therefore, the goal of this study was to establish a novel tissue engineered model system of aging human myocardium that can be used to better understand of how diseases progress with aging and to investigate the effect of aging tissue microenvironment on cell survival after a heart attack/myocardial infarction (MI). Our hypothesis was that biochemical composition and biophysical properties like stiffness of aging tissue microenvironment (ECM) would affect the cell survival after MI by altering cellular communication. 

 

We thoroughly characterized human and mouse heart tissues and identified biochemical and biophysical alterations with aging. Using young (1-3-month), adult (6-9-month) and aged (22-24-month) mice and young (<30-year-old) and aged (>60-year-old) human hearts, we studied the cell-ECM interplay and the effect of aging on human iPSC-derived cardiomyocyte function as well as survival after MI. We showed that ECM age was as important as cellular age in cardiac aging. Specifically, we showed that aged ECM presented aging cues that accelerated the aging phenotype and impaired cardiac function and stress defense machinery, while young ECM increased proliferation and adult ECM improved cardiac function. We then created MI-mimicking stress conditions for young and aged iCMs and investigated the ECM effect on the cell survival, and post-MI recovery. Although young cells showed no ECM-age dependent response, aged cells expressed considerably more apoptosis-related proteins and low survival when cultured on aged ECM. Similarly, we characterized human iPSC-derived cardiomyocytes (iCM) with respect to culture aged (1-, 3-, 6- and 14-months) and verified chronological aging as well as age-related functional deterioration in vitro, resembling aged human and animal heart tissue. Aged iCMs had impaired function and stress coping machinery, hence were more susceptible to MI-mimicking stress conditions. We also found out that once cells were put in aged human heart stiffness, resulting model tissues behave similar to aged human heart, showing impaired stress response and cardioprotection. 

Establishing the basis, we created 3D cardiac tissue models with human cells along with materials that resemble the natural environment of the heart and investigated cellular communication under conditions that mimic a heart attack, such as low oxygen, limited nutrients, reperfusion (restoring blood flow), and oxidative stress.

 We first developed a native tissue stiffness matching aged tissue model consisting cells treated to exhibit senescence markers, and a synthetic polymer, poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG). We investigated the effect of cell-cell interactions and cooperative effects in aged tissue failure by altering the degree of the intercellular communication between the cells (i.e., dependent vs non-dependent populations). We showed that the disruption of cell-cell interactions in an interdependent population is the essential cause of aging and systemic aging can happen even without cellular level aging. We also showed that having functional neighbors is more important than being stress-free, as the young cells survived the oxidative stress better only when the population was dense. 

Finally, we used the extrusion-based 3D printing of various hydrogels (i.e., GelMA, MeHA) with the addition of decellularized human cardiac tissue ECM. We fully characterized the mechanical properties of these hydrogels and evaluated the cell compatibilities. Leveraging the stiffness difference between obtained hydrogels, we fabricated 3D in vitro MI models to study MI recovery and potential therapies including cardiac patches and cell injection with human cells. We then modeled post-MI fibrotic tissue with 3 distinct regions as remote, border, and scar. We developed a novel methodology and used multiple bioinks with the addition of aged type I collagen, at variable concentrations with different cell types, including aged iCMs, endothelial cells, cardiac fibroblasts, and cardiac myofibroblasts. Following successful printing, we verified the cell viability and the cell types that comprised each region. This is the first study which accomplishes the 3D bioprinting of a post-MI tissue model while accounting for both the biomolecular and biomechanical changes in the in vivo post-MI infarct region.

All in all, we presented 3D tissue-engineered models of aged heart with newly developed bioinks and printing method to mimic human physiological conditions in vitro, providing a crucial bridge between 2D in vitro and expensive long in vivo and clinical studies. These engineered aged post-MI tissue models serve as benchtop platforms to assess the therapeutics on aged cardiac tissue. 

In addition, we were committed to integrating education and training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students. We organized a workshop called "Peace through Science" that aims to promote inclusivity and tolerance through scientific engagement.

 


Last Modified: 06/21/2023
Modified by: Pinar Zorlutuna
por.por_txt_cntn:
Cardiovascular diseases (CVD) are the leading cause of death. CVD occur more often in the older people, as aging is the primary risk factor. Current animal models and simple cell cultures fall short to fully mimic the disease progression in the aged human heart. Therefore, the goal of this study was to establish a novel tissue engineered model system of aging human myocardium that can be used to better understand of how diseases progress with aging and to investigate the effect of aging tissue microenvironment on cell survival after a heart attack/myocardial infarction (MI). Our hypothesis was that biochemical composition and biophysical properties like stiffness of aging tissue microenvironment (ECM) would affect the cell survival after MI by altering cellular communication. 

 

We thoroughly characterized human and mouse heart tissues and identified biochemical and biophysical alterations with aging. Using young (1-3-month), adult (6-9-month) and aged (22-24-month) mice and young (<30-year-old) and aged (>60-year-old) human hearts, we studied the cell-ECM interplay and the effect of aging on human iPSC-derived cardiomyocyte function as well as survival after MI. We showed that ECM age was as important as cellular age in cardiac aging. Specifically, we showed that aged ECM presented aging cues that accelerated the aging phenotype and impaired cardiac function and stress defense machinery, while young ECM increased proliferation and adult ECM improved cardiac function. We then created MI-mimicking stress conditions for young and aged iCMs and investigated the ECM effect on the cell survival, and post-MI recovery. Although young cells showed no ECM-age dependent response, aged cells expressed considerably more apoptosis-related proteins and low survival when cultured on aged ECM. Similarly, we characterized human iPSC-derived cardiomyocytes (iCM) with respect to culture aged (1-, 3-, 6- and 14-months) and verified chronological aging as well as age-related functional deterioration in vitro, resembling aged human and animal heart tissue. Aged iCMs had impaired function and stress coping machinery, hence were more susceptible to MI-mimicking stress conditions. We also found out that once cells were put in aged human heart stiffness, resulting model tissues behave similar to aged human heart, showing impaired stress response and cardioprotection. 

Establishing the basis, we created 3D cardiac tissue models with human cells along with materials that resemble the natural environment of the heart and investigated cellular communication under conditions that mimic a heart attack, such as low oxygen, limited nutrients, reperfusion (restoring blood flow), and oxidative stress.

 We first developed a native tissue stiffness matching aged tissue model consisting cells treated to exhibit senescence markers, and a synthetic polymer, poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG). We investigated the effect of cell-cell interactions and cooperative effects in aged tissue failure by altering the degree of the intercellular communication between the cells (i.e., dependent vs non-dependent populations). We showed that the disruption of cell-cell interactions in an interdependent population is the essential cause of aging and systemic aging can happen even without cellular level aging. We also showed that having functional neighbors is more important than being stress-free, as the young cells survived the oxidative stress better only when the population was dense. 

Finally, we used the extrusion-based 3D printing of various hydrogels (i.e., GelMA, MeHA) with the addition of decellularized human cardiac tissue ECM. We fully characterized the mechanical properties of these hydrogels and evaluated the cell compatibilities. Leveraging the stiffness difference between obtained hydrogels, we fabricated 3D in vitro MI models to study MI recovery and potential therapies including cardiac patches and cell injection with human cells. We then modeled post-MI fibrotic tissue with 3 distinct regions as remote, border, and scar. We developed a novel methodology and used multiple bioinks with the addition of aged type I collagen, at variable concentrations with different cell types, including aged iCMs, endothelial cells, cardiac fibroblasts, and cardiac myofibroblasts. Following successful printing, we verified the cell viability and the cell types that comprised each region. This is the first study which accomplishes the 3D bioprinting of a post-MI tissue model while accounting for both the biomolecular and biomechanical changes in the in vivo post-MI infarct region.

All in all, we presented 3D tissue-engineered models of aged heart with newly developed bioinks and printing method to mimic human physiological conditions in vitro, providing a crucial bridge between 2D in vitro and expensive long in vivo and clinical studies. These engineered aged post-MI tissue models serve as benchtop platforms to assess the therapeutics on aged cardiac tissue. 

In addition, we were committed to integrating education and training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students. We organized a workshop called "Peace through Science" that aims to promote inclusivity and tolerance through scientific engagement.
